title: FP 1.2 — Questions, Questions, Questions…
author: Seán Muggivan
objective: To explore curiosity as the foundation of research by learning to ask progressively deeper questions about visible, hidden, and systemic aspects of a phenomenon.

instructions.overview: Questions perpetuate investigation and discovery. Answers imply completion. This reflective activity invites you to delay answers as long as possible and build your capacity for inquiry.
instructions.mechanics: Write in full sentences with proper punctuation and capitalization. Each question should feel complete and precise. Let your writing flow—avoid lists or fragments.
instructions.reminder: If the door to discovery is a question, an answer is the lock. Leave the door unlocked.

sections.title: The Apparent Story
sections.prompt: Begin by describing what you can see about the house. Ask questions about its visible details. What draws your attention first?

sections.title: The Less Apparent Story
sections.prompt: Imagine who lived there last and why they might have left. What clues suggest a story? Keep asking questions rather than assuming answers.

sections.title: The Even Less Apparent Story
sections.prompt: Step back further. What was happening in the neighborhood, city, or society while this house was being abandoned? Ask about the systems surrounding your topic.

sections.title: Collective Reflection
sections.prompt: All student questions from this activity will be analyzed by a local AI model to identify recurring themes and patterns of curiosity. From these, 3–5 potential DSFP research questions may emerge.

reflection_instructions: When you finish, reread your questions. Notice how your perspective shifted from concrete observation to abstract inquiry. How did your curiosity evolve?

criteria: Full participation in all three writing stages
Use of correct punctuation and capitalization
